Graphical abstract Catalytic ozone decomposition on various manganese oxide-based catalysts was investigated at 40 °C for ozone concentrations in the range 2–20 ppm in dry and humid conditions. Ozone conversion efficiency shows a slight dependence with ozone concentration, slightly decreasing when ozone concentration increases. A strong but reversible inhibiting effect was observed when water is present in the gas phase likely due to the reversible adsorption of water on ozone reaction sites. Whatever the catalyst used, the same behavior was observed which is characterized by a transient decrease in efficiency at the beginning of the reaction until reaching the steady-state. A kinetic model was developed, based on the mechanism of ozone decomposition proposed by Oyama and co-workers, allowing us to properly describe the reaction behavior of ozone on manganese oxide catalysts for variable initial reactant concentrations. Additionally, the transient behavior of the MnO2 catalysts experimentally observed at the beginning of the ozone decomposition reaction was kinetically described for the first time, as well as the steady-state. Keywords Ozone decomposition Humidity influence Kinetic model Transient behavior Manganese oxides 1 Introduction Ozone is a highly oxidizing gas mainly used in disinfection or in water treatment due to its biocide properties. Unfortunately ozone is also highly toxic for human health, even at low concentration levels. Usually, the ozone concentration in the lower atmosphere does not exceed few ppb, but in specific conditions due to air pollution this value can reach more than 200 ppb, thereby provoking health problems. In stratosphere, ozone is formed by direct action of UV radiation from sun light on oxygen molecules and its concentration increases with altitude until 25 km, forming the so-called ozone layer, essential for its role of UV filtration. At the ground level, independently of naturally occurring ozone or ozone intentionally produced for water treatment or disinfection, some apparatuses as laser printers, photocopiers or electrical devices can also produce ozone, thereby increasing its concentration in these rooms to a higher level than the requested one for human safe exposition (60 ppb for long term exposure, 120 ppb for short exposition) [1]. Moreover, during a long distance flight at an altitude between 10–12 km (30,000–40,000 feet), air passengers and crew members may be exposed to a high ozone concentration environment since outdoor air which is used to renew the cabin air contains between 1–2 ppm of ozone [2]. The ventilated air therefore requires ozone removal so as to preserve human health. Ozone is a metastable gas whose natural decomposition (ΔG° at 298 K = −163 kJ/mol) at ambient temperature is rather low but increases with temperature (Table 1 ) [3]. Ozone may however be efficiently converted at low temperature with the help of a variety of catalysts [3–6]. Catalytic ozone decomposition has been mainly reported over bulk or supported transition metal oxides, eventually doped by noble metals. Among them, manganese-based catalysts were shown to exhibit the highest efficiency in decomposing ozone [4,7–9]. The mechanism of ozone decomposition on manganese oxide-based catalysts proposed by Oyama and co-workers [4,10–12] is now commonly admitted (Scheme 1 ). The first step is the reaction of ozone with an oxygen vacancy leading to the formation of molecular oxygen O2 and atomic oxygen adsorbed on the catalyst O*, then a second molecule of ozone can react with the atomic oxygen to form a peroxide species O2* and another O2 molecule. Finally, the peroxide species decomposes leading to gas phase O2 along with an oxygen vacancy on the catalyst. With the aim of improving understanding of ozone decomposition on manganese oxide catalysts, we have studied the catalytic ozone elimination on unsupported and alumina supported manganese oxides in terms of influence of time on stream, initial reactant concentrations, relative humidity, catalyst composition and catalyst surface area. A kinetic model based on the mechanism of Oyama and co-workers was proposed in order to describe the catalytic behavior observed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of alumina supported manganese oxides Various highly porous γ-alumina supported manganese oxide doped with copper or palladium were synthesized according to a method similar to that reported by Bleta et al. for a different boehmite (AlOOH) precursor [13]. Here a highly dispersible commercial boehmite powder (Disperal P2®, Sasol) was used to synthesize a boehmite nanoparticle hydrosol, prior to the addition of a non ionic triblock copolymer (Pluronic® F127, EO100PO65EO100) and metal nitrates. An appropriate mass of powder was introduced in water at pH = 4 so as to achieve the desired aluminum concentration. After 12 h of agitation, the boehmite sol is recovered by filtration. Pluronic® F127 was added in the sol and the mixture kept under gentle stirring for 24 h at room temperature. The ratio of ethoxy units (EO) to the number of aluminum atom is equal to 1.5. Then manganese and copper nitrates (or palladium nitrate) were introduced into the sol containing the copolymer and stirred for 12 h prior the sols being dried in PFTE plates at 70 °C for 12 h. The manganese and copper (or palladium) content is equal to 5 wt.% and 1 wt.%, respectively. Finally, the xerogels were calcined at 500 °C under air. The porous alumina sample containing Mn and Cu was referred to as 5Mn-1Cu/Al2O3, while the corresponding Mn and Pd counterpart was labeled as 5Mn-1Pd/Al2O3. 2.2 Synthesis of unsupported manganese oxides A porous octahedral birnessite-type manganese oxide was prepared using a microemulsion process consisting of benzyl alcohol (BA), sodium dodecylsulfate (SDS) and water, along with a KMnO4 solution as manganese precursor. Benzyl alcohol was used as reducing agent of the high-valence manganese precursor solution. The synthesis procedure was adapted from the protocol described in reference [14]. In brief, BA and SDS were dissolved in water under stirring (weight composition of the BA/SDS/H2O mixture = 30/16/84). KMnO4 (3 wt.%) was then added dropwise into the solution under stirring at room temperature, yielding a brown precipitate. The resulting mixture was heated under hydrothermal conditions at 80 °C for 2 h. The solid was recovered by filtration, washed with water and ethanol and dried at 120 °C prior to being calcined at 400 °C for 2 h in air. The MnO2 sample synthesized in the presence of benzyl alcohol and sodium dodecylsulfate was referred to as MnO2-BAS. A second synthesis route involving the use of a strong organic reducing agent under mild conditions was also carried out to prepare a manganese oxide with a high surface area value based on the following procedure [15]. A solution of ascorbic acid was slowly added dropwise to a stirred 0.2 mol/L KMnO4 solution placed in an ice-water bath (molar ratio of oxidant to reducing agent of 10:1). The pH was kept constant to 3 using an automated pH titrator. At the end of the addition, the precipitate was recovered by filtration, washed with water and dried overnight at 60 °C. Pure octahedral δ-MnO2 single phase with a surface area of 174 m2/g was obtained by using the ascorbic acid route. Such δ-MnO2 sample was labeled as MnO2-AA. Table 2 gathered the surface area values, as well as the manganese and doping element content of the catalysts. The textural, structural and morphology characteristics of the MnO2 samples are summarized in Table 3 . 2.3 Ozone generation and analysis The catalytic activity tests were carried out in a conventional flow reactor at atmospheric pressure at 40 °C. Ozone was generated by a home-made apparatus by flowing pure oxygen through a non-thermal plasma reactor. Then the exiting ozone/oxygen mixture was diluted by air. For humid conditions, water was introduced in the gas flow by bubbling a part of the air flow in a saturator-type vessel containing water prior to being mixed with ozone-air mixture. The amount of water was fixed by controlling the temperature of the saturator by a cryostat. The humidity was fixed to 10% of relative humidity at 25 °C, corresponding to 3130 ppm of water in the final gas flow. Ozone was analyzed online by an ozone analyzer (Environnement S.A. type O3 42 M) based on the UV photometric method at 254 nm. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Estimation of mass transfer limitations Determination of reaction rate in heterogeneous catalysis is a difficult task since the experimental measurements can be largely spoiled by mass transfer limitations. Two kind of mass transfer limitations can indeed occur: (i) from gas phase to the catalytic active surface (external diffusion) and (ii) within the porosity of the catalyst (internal diffusion). In order to be confident with the experimental measurements, some criteria have been proposed based on the reaction experimental conditions and the physical-chemical parameters of the catalyst. The Mears criterion C M = R . r p C b . k c . [16] can be used to determine if external diffusion limitation occurs, whereas the Weisz and Prater criterion Cw = R . r p 2 C s . D E [17,18] is used to evaluate a possible limitation due to internal mass transfer. If C M is less than 0.15, the measured experimental rate is not affected by the external diffusion. And if the value of the second criterion Cw = R . r p 2 C s . D E is less than 0.6, no intraparticle diffusion occurs (with R =reaction rate, r p =mean radius of catalyst particles, C b and C s =reactant concentration, k c =mass transfer coefficient, D E = diffusion coefficient). According to the data listed in Table S1, the Mears C M criterion was calculated to be equal to 0.07, which is very far from the limit value of 0.15 [16], indicating that our experimental measurements are not affected by external diffusion. By calculation, the value of the Weisz and Prater criterion Cw is 18.9, thereby pointing out a strong intraparticle diffusion limitation, which suggests that almost no reaction occurs inside the catalyst porosity. The discussion and detailed calculations are presented in full in the Electronic Supplementary Information (ESI) file. 3.2 Catalytic activity in dry and humid conditions Fig. 1 shows the ozone decomposition activity over two different MnOx-M/Al2O3 catalysts (with M = Cu or Pd) in dry and humid conditions. Whatever the catalyst, the ozone conversion was 90% after 4 h of reaction in dry conditions. By contrast, a strong influence of the nature of the doping element on the activity of the MnOx/alumina catalysts was noticed in humid conditions. A pronounced decrease in ozone conversion efficiency was indeed observed for the catalyst without palladium under humid conditions (RH = 10%), indicating a strong inhibiting effect of water on ozone decomposition over the copper doped Mn/Al2O3 catalyst. By contrast, the 5Mn-1Pd/Al2O3 catalyst showed a small decrease in ozone decomposition efficiency. The beneficial effect of palladium on limiting the decrease of ozone decomposition efficiency in the presence of water was already observed [2,19–22], although several authors did not observed any inhibiting effect of water vapor [3,4,6,7,23]. This discrepancy could be explained by the presence of NOx inside the reactor when air is used instead of oxygen to generate ozone. The NOx produced was indeed shown to hide the effect of water as demonstrated by Subrahmanyam et al. on activated carbon [24] and Mehandjiev et al. on manganese oxide-based catalysts [25–27]. The inhibiting effect of water is likely due to the blocking of the ozone reaction sites (probably Lewis acid sites) by molecular water adsorption [20,28]. Suppressing water in the gas flow restored the conversion efficiency observed in dry conditions (Fig. 2 ), suggesting that water inhibition is not due to any catalyst modification but rather to water adsorption on ozone decomposition active sites [20,28]. If NOx species are produced in the gas flow, adsorbed water could react with them to form nitric and/or nitrous acid. This results in the suppression of water and NOx species in the gas phase and in the releasing of the sites for the ozone reaction. The role of palladium may be to promote the electron transfer to manganese, which contributes to the water desorption from manganese cations [19,20,29]. It is also worth mentioning that whatever the Mn-based catalyst (supported or not) or the reaction conditions (dry or humid air), the conversion behavior as a function of time on stream followed the same trend with a decrease in ozone conversion during the first minutes of reaction until reaching a steady state (Figs. 1 and 2). 3.3 Effect of ozone concentration According to the mechanism of ozone decomposition (Scheme 1), it is expected that the kinetic behavior was not exactly first-order with respect to ozone. Oyama et al. have proposed the kinetic law r = k.[O3]α with α = 0.94 to describe the behavior of ozone decomposition on manganese oxides for high partial pressure values of O3 [6,7]. Here, we have studied the influence of the initial ozone concentration on its conversion on two manganese oxides exhibiting different specific surface area values (Table 3) to complement the experimental observation previously made by Oyama and co-workers. The behavior of ozone conversion was examined by using four different initial ozone concentrations (2, 5, 13 and 20 ppm) in dry conditions. The results are shown in Fig. 3 . At steady-state, both δ-MnO2 catalysts exhibited the same behavior with a slight decrease in ozone conversion when initial ozone concentration increased. By considering the same kinetic law than that of Oyama et al., we also found a value of α equal to 0.94, but with a satisfactory fit only for the lowest initial ozone concentration (2 ppm). However, this kinetic law is based on the experimental behavior of ozone conversion when the initial ozone concentration varied and does not take into account the expected mechanism of ozone decomposition (Scheme 1). Additionally, the transient behavior observed whatever the catalyst being used, should also be considered in any kinetic description of ozone catalytic decomposition. According to this mechanism, ozone is adsorbed on catalyst oxygen vacancies to form O− or O2- surface intermediates (Reaction (1)) by electron transfer from manganese cations and oxygen molecules released in the gas phase [6,7,15,22,30–32]. A further reaction of ozone on these oxygen species leads to the formation of a peroxide species and another oxygen molecule (Reaction (2)) [6,7,28]. Finally, peroxide species decompose to molecular O2 and release an oxygen vacancy on the catalyst surface (Reaction (3)) [5–7]. (1) O3 +* → O2 + O* (2) O3 +O* → O2* + O2 (3) O2* → O2 +* with * being an active site The efficiency in ozone decomposition has been related to the propensity of oxygen vacancies being formed [5,22,28,30–32]. The presence of peroxo surface intermediate species was evidenced by Raman spectroscopy [4,6,7,26] and their decomposition to molecular O2 and oxygen vacancies are expected to be the rate limiting step of the reaction [5–7]. From the generally admitted mechanism and in the classical hypothesis of pseudo first order law, we could assume that rate (R1) of step (1) depends on the ozone partial pressure (or gas concentration) and on the fraction (θ*) of total reaction sites able to react with ozone (* = oxygen vacancy). The reactants concentration varies either continuously within the reactor (plug-flow type reactor) or the concentration is constant in the reactor and equal to the exiting concentration (case of perfectly mixed reactor). In practice, the behavior of experimental reactors is intermediate between these two ideal cases and depends on several parameters (linear speed of the gas flow, geometry of the reactor, disposition of the catalytic bed…). A plug-flow reactor can always be modeled by successive perfectly mixed reactors and, hence, at low conversion both types of reactors behave identically. Whatever the behavior of the model reactors, the results presented in Table 5 showed quite a correlation between the simulated values derived from the kinetic model and the experimental data. However, it is difficult to conclude on the reactor behavior between the plug-flow or the perfectly mixed reactor, since the difference between experimental and simulated results is too small. From the experimental data, the variation of ozone conversion as a function of residence time can be estimated for each kind of reactor and for both δ-MnO2 catalysts (MnO2-BAS and MnO2-AA). The conversion of ozone was expressed as a function of the total surface of the catalyst inside the reactor with the aim of comparing more accurately MnO2-BAS and MnO2-AA catalysts. The residence time is calculated as the ratio between the free volume of the catalytic bed divided by the flow rate. This parameter is analogous to the ratio between the amount of catalyst divided by the flow rate, as well as to the total surface of the catalyst in the reactor divided by the flow rate (catalyst surface area = mcata x BET surface area). τ = free volume flow rate ⇔ catalyst weight flow rate ⇔ Catalyst weight x specific surface area flow rate = catalyst surface flow rate For a constant flow rate, the conversion can be expressed only as a function of the total surface of the catalyst in the reactor (Fig. 6 ). Surprisingly, both MnO2 catalysts seemed to behave similarly. The behavior being probably intermediate between the plug-flow and perfectly mixed reactor model. The main difference between these two catalysts is their specific surface area value. 3.4 Transient behavior of the MnO2 catalysts Whatever the catalyst used, a decrease in ozone conversion was observed during the first minutes of reaction before a plateau being reached where the conversion remained stable. We have also performed a second catalytic experiment by reusing the MnO2 catalysts. The same transient behavior and conversion value at steady state were observed with the reused catalysts, suggesting that no irreversible transformation occurred during the transient behavior. This behavior may be consistent with the mechanism we have proposed, provided Reaction (1) is fast compared with Reactions (2) and (3), as suggested by several authors. However, to the best of our knowledge, the kinetic description of this transient behavior was never reported so far. To gather further information on this temporal phenomenon, the previous set of Eqs. (4)–(6) was employed to describe the transient behavior of the MnO2 catalysts. According to these equations, the ozone decomposition rate should depend on the amount of relative sites symbolized by *, O* and O2* in Eqs. (1)–(3) and hence corresponding to Mnn+, Mn-O and Mn-O2. The rates of transformation of these sites can be expressed by d θ * dt = − R 1 + R 3 a n d d θ * = − R 1 + R 3 . dt dθo dt = R 1 − R 2 a n d d θ o = R 1 – R 2 . dt dθ o 2 dt = R 2 − R 3 a n d d θ o 2 = R 2 – R 3 . dt At the time t, these rates can be calculated as dθ* = θ*t+dt − θ*t; dθo = θot+dt - θot ; dθo2 = θo2 t+dt − θo2 t And by combining with the preceding equations and expressions of R1 to R3 rates, the following expressions can be obtained which allowed us to calculate the values of θ*, θo and θo2 for the time t + dt. θ* t+dt = θ*t.(1 -k1.θ*t.Po3.dt) + k3.θo2.dt θot+dt = θot.(1-k2.Po3.dt) + k1.θ*t.Po3.dt θo2 t+dt = θo2 t.(1-k3.dt) + k2.θot.Po3.dt The ozone decomposition rate expression is dPo3 = −(R1 + R2).dt In the case of a perfectly mixed reactor, it comes P°o3 – Po3 = (R1 + R2).τ where τ = residence time. The ozone conversion expression in this case would be at the time t X t = ( k 1 θ * t + k 2 θ o t ) τ 1 + ( k 1 θ * t + k 2 θ o t ) τ A simulation can be performed by calculating the values of θ*, θo and θo2 by small increment of t from t = 0 for which it is expected that θ* = 1 and θo = θo2 = 0. As shown in part 3.2, our catalytic reactor behaves intermediately between a plug-flow and a perfectly mixed reactor, so that as early demonstrated this kind of non-ideal behavior can be easily modeled by several successive perfectly mixed reactors [33,34]. The modeling of our reactor behavior was then carried out by considering three successive identical perfectly mixed reactors. Constant k1 could be roughly estimated from the initial ozone conversion. Since at t = 0, the values of θ* and θo (θo2) are likely to be 1 and 0 respectively, the ozone decomposition rate reduces to d P O 3 d t = - k 1 . P O 3 and ln (1-X) = k1.τ where X = ozone conversion If we arbitrary choose τ = 1, the kinetic constants for our model are deduced from the values of Table 4. For both MnO2-BAS and MnO2-AA catalysts, the set of constants reported in Table 6 were used to draw the simulation of the transient behavior as a function of time on stream (Fig. 7 a and b). Such values allowed us to simulate the transient behavior experimentally observed at the beginning of time of stream for each catalyst, as well as the ozone conversion values at steady state. From these values, the percentage of the different sites could be calculated at steady state for various initial ozone concentrations for both types of model reactors (plug-flow and perfectly mixed) (Table 7 ). For the plug-flow reactor, it appeared that the values of sites percentage varied continuously between the entrance (θin) and the exit of the reactor (θout) according to the local value of the ozone concentration. In the case of the perfectly mixed reactor, the values to be considered are the θout values, since in this kind of reactor it is assumed that the ozone concentration is constant in the whole reactor and equal to the value at the exit of the reactor. The values reported in Table 7 pointed out that for the lowest ozone concentration the sites coverage by atomic oxygen species is more important than that by peroxide species, thereby suggesting that the rate limiting step is the reaction of ozone on adsorbed atomic oxygen (Reaction (2)). For higher ozone concentration, the coverage of surface peroxide species becomes much higher than that of atomic oxygen species as already observed by Oyama et al. [10,11]. As an example, with a concentration of ozone of 100 ppm, the coverage of peroxo species is equal to 64% for MnO2-BAS and to 79% for MnO2-AA according to our calculations. In these conditions, this indicates that the rate limiting step should be the molecular oxygen desorption from the decomposition of peroxide surface intermediates (Reaction (3)). 4 Conclusion Ozone decomposition was studied at 40 °C over manganese oxide catalysts exhibiting varying textural properties, as well as on alumina supported manganese oxides in dry and humid conditions. In particular, the steady-state and transient kinetics of the ozone decomposition reaction were investigated for ozone concentrations in the range 2–20 ppm. Whatever the catalyst used, a transient decrease in ozone conversion efficiency systematically occurred at the beginning of the reaction until reaching the steady-state. In the presence of water in the gas phase, a strong inhibiting effect in ozone decomposition efficiency was observed for manganese oxide catalysts whereas addition of small amount of palladium was shown to strongly limit this detrimental effect. The inhibiting effect of water is likely due to water molecules adsorbed on active sites, thereby blocking their access to ozone molecules with as a result a drop in the catalyst efficiency by decreasing the amount of active sites. This effect is however reversible since the initial efficiency was fully restored by suppressing water in the gas phase. A kinetic model was developed to explain the reaction behavior of ozone on manganese oxide catalysts for variable initial reactant concentrations. The kinetic description of the transient behavior of the MnO2 catalysts experimentally observed at the beginning of the reaction was carried out for the first time, as well as the steady-state. With this kinetic model, the relative amount of manganese active sites for ozone decomposition could be calculated, thereby pointing out that sites covered by atomic oxygen are the most abundant at steady-state. This suggests that for low ozone concentration the rate limiting step is the reaction of ozone on surface atomic oxygen to form peroxo surface intermediates. Such result is not in contradiction with the conclusions previously made by Oyama and co-workers who found that the main surface species were the peroxide species for high partial pressure of ozone. In their case, the value of the partial pressure of ozone was more than hundred times the range of ozone concentration used in this work (2–20 ppm = 0.2–2 Pa). A simple calculation of θo2, for example with MnO2-BAS catalyst, with our kinetic constants for an ozone partial pressure of 100 Pa (1000 ppm) leads to a value of θo2 higher than 90%. These results confirm that our kinetic model is suitable to properly describe the catalytic behavior of ozone decomposition in a large range of ozone concentration. The observed low difference in conversion between both MnO2 catalysts (only a factor of 1.75), whereas the specific surface area of MnO2 AA is about three times higher than that of MnO2 BAS is consistent with the intraparticle mass transfer limitation, thereby suggesting that the reaction occurs only on the external surface of the catalyst. coredata.dc:description: Catalytic ozone decomposition on various manganese oxide-based catalysts was investigated at 40 °C for ozone concentrations in the range 2–20 ppm in dry and humid conditions. Ozone conversion efficiency shows a slight dependence with ozone concentration, slightly decreasing when ozone concentration increases. A strong but reversible inhibiting effect was observed when water is present in the gas phase likely due to the reversible adsorption of water on ozone reaction sites. Whatever the catalyst used, the same behavior was observed which is characterized by a transient decrease in efficiency at the beginning of the reaction until reaching the steady-state. A kinetic model was developed, based on the mechanism of ozone decomposition proposed by Oyama and co-workers, allowing us to properly describe the reaction behavior of ozone on manganese oxide catalysts for variable initial reactant concentrations. Additionally, the transient behavior of the MnO2 catalysts experimentally observed at the beginning of the ozone decomposition reaction was kinetically described for the first time, as well as the steady-state.
coredata.dc:title: Near-ambient temperature ozone decomposition kinetics on manganese oxide-based catalysts
